question.feedback: B is correct. 0,1 The postfix operators take one operator and either increment or decrement the value. Although these operators are unary operators, they are classified separately from the rest of the unary operators because of their higher precedence and special behavior. When a postfix operator is used as part of a larger expression, the expression's value is returned before the postfix operator is processed. For example, the above code shows how the value of the expression xNum++ is returned before the value is incremented

item.question: Consider the following sample code, what will be output in the trace statement? Choose one. var xNum:Number = 0;trace(xNum++);trace(xNum);

question.feedback: A is correct. 1,1 The unary operators take one operand. The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators in this group are prefixoperators, which means that they appear before the operand in an expression. The prefix operators differ from their postfix counterparts in that the increment or decrement operation is completed before the value of the overall expression is returned. For example, the above code shows how the value of the expression ++xNum is returned after the value is incremented

item.question: Consider the following sample code, what will be output in the trace statement? Choose one. var xNum:Number = 0;trace(++xNum);trace(xNum);
